items.title: Dental Crown Treatment
items.summary: Dental Crown Treatment Dr. Bellisario ensures that all patients are suitable candidates for dental crowns before they begin treatment. If needed, he will recommend dental extractions, periodontal care, or root canals to ensure that patients are in good oral health. For patients who need a…
items.content_html:
Dental Crown Treatment

Dr. Bellisario ensures that all patients are suitable candidates for dental crowns before they begin treatment. If needed, he will recommend dental extractions, periodontal care, or root canals to ensure that patients are in good oral health. For patients who need a tooth crown to cap off a dental implant, Dr. Bellisario makes sure that they have enough jaw bone tissue to support their implant. Then, he will begin their dental crown treatment.

First, Dr. Bellisario will prepare the tooth for the crown. He removes a small portion of the enamel to make sure that the tooth crowns fit properly. Then, he takes dental impressions. The impressions are then sent to the dental laboratory where they are fabricated to exact specifications. Once the dental crowns are complete, Dr. Bellisario attaches the crowns to the teeth. After a dental implant procedure, patients who need crowns will have to wait until their implants heal to receive their crowns.

Dental crowns are durable if taken care of properly. Keep your teeth clean and flossing daily to care for dental crowns. By taking care of your gums and natural teeth, you can reduce the risk of tooth decay and gum disease. We can replace any damaged or old dental crowns. We can help you create your custom restoration.

All-Ceramic

All-ceramic crowns are made from zirconia and aluminous. They provide a metal-free esthetic option with a number of benefits.

An all-ceramic crown with reduced material thickness can be made by eliminating the requirement for a supportive metal core. This makes it a more favorable treatment choice in areas with limited space. Additionally, the elimination of the metal core allows for light transmission through the porcelain for better optical, life-like properties and a higher level of aesthetics.

While all-ceramic materials are advancing in strength and endurance, it is important to be cautious about areas that require heavy functionality. Continuing research is exploring the significant vulnerabilities of the porcelain systems in such areas.

Protecting damaged teeth with dental crowns

Doctor Robert A. Milner Medically reviewed

Recovery

Dental crowns, also known as "caps," preserve the functionality of damaged teeth. Common dental restorations can be used to repair or restore function of damaged teeth, replace an existing crown, and protect cracked teeth. This custom-designed tooth restoration covers a damaged tooth. Dentists today have a variety of conservative treatment options through which to restore teeth. These options should all be discussed and explored before deciding on a full-coverage crown.

items.title: Potential Complications With Your Dental Crown
items.summary: You may have a problem with the crown of your tooth, as with all dental procedures. Some possible complications include the following: It is common to feel some pain after a crown is placed on a tooth. However, it is rare for you to experience…
items.content_html:
Potential Complications With Your Dental Crown

You may have a problem with the crown of your tooth, as with all dental procedures. Some possible complications include the following:

It is common to feel some pain after a crown is placed on a tooth. However, it is rare for you to experience severe or constant discomfort. If any pain or discomfort does not subside within a few hours, you should contact the dental office. The crown may have to be adjusted if the edges are causing irritation to your gums and adjacent teeth. If the tooth under the dental crown has severe, ongoing pain, it may have experienced trauma during the procedure and need attention.

Increased Sensitivity External stimuli cannot cause tooth irritation, so enamel protects the tooth's surface. Sensitivity to hot or cold liquids and foods can occur if the enamel thickness decreases.

Bite Issues: A dental crown changes the tooth's shape and size. Your bite may shift or become uncomfortable when it comes into contact with other teeth. You can adjust the crown to make it fit better with your other teeth.

If your dental crown is not taken care of properly, or you suffer from facial trauma, it may become cracked or damaged. The dental crown could also fall off if it becomes too large or the cement that holds it in place is damaged. If your crown falls or becomes damaged, contact your dentist right away.

How Much Does a Tooth Crown Cost?

Costhelper has estimated that the current price range for dental crowns per tooth is:

  • Gold crowns are available in a range of prices, from $600-$2,500
  • All-porcelain crowns can range between $800-$3,000
  • Porcelain-fused-to-metal crowns can cost $500-$1,500
  • Zirconia Crowns and E-max crowns cost approximately the same as all- porcelain crowns

If you have insurance, about 50% of the crown can be covered. However, it all depends on what type of insurance you have and the facts of your case.

Your insurance will not pay for the cost of the crown if it is part of cosmetic treatments. If the procedure is preventative, such as to cover root canals or fix broken teeth, your insurance may be able to pay for the costs.

items.title: The Best Dentist Crown Material
items.summary: The Best Dentist Crown Material Every material has its advantages and disadvantages. The crown material that you choose will be based on the type of teeth being capped and the aesthetic needs of your mouth. Ceramic Dental crowns are crafted in a lab and built…
items.content_html:
The Best Dentist Crown Material

Every material has its advantages and disadvantages. The crown material that you choose will be based on the type of teeth being capped and the aesthetic needs of your mouth.

Ceramic Dental crowns are crafted in a lab and built up layer by layer, sometimes with the help of CAD/CAM dental technology. This gives them the same slightly translucent appearance of natural teeth and makes them a popular choice for front teeth that will be on show. You can even create them chairside with a new technology that mills crowns in a matter of minutes. These are great because they can be completed in only one visit with no need for a provisional cap.

The downside of any ceramic material is that, although it is very strong, it is more brittle than metal and liable to crack or chip over time, but when fabricated correctly, they should be expected to last 15+ years. Some ceramic crowns, like Emax caps, are designed differently to be more durable.

Gold dental crowns and those made from other alloy metals tend to be much more durable. They have the added benefit of being biocompatible with teeth, which means the capped teeth shouldn't cause any damage or wear to the teeth they bite against. If the patient takes care of it, a gold crown will last for a long time.

Any metal crown has one major drawback: the color. Many people simply don't want a gold- or silver-colored tooth on show, even if it is tucked away at the back.

For others, having a gold tooth crown is quite appealing and they may go as far as to have it engraved or studded with gemstones!

Tooth cap prices can vary from one clinic to another, as with all dental treatments. It's worth shopping around and comparing prices between dentists near you, especially if you need to get more than one of your teeth crowned.

There is also more to consider than just the cost of a tooth cap; as discussed above, there are pros and cons to each type of crown. In addition to asking your dentist about dental crown costs, inquire about the different options that may be suitable for you. It is a good idea to inquire about the options available to you from your dentist if you find yourself in similar circumstances.

Full ceramic crowns, on the other hand, are more expensive than full metal ones. Because they require more work to look natural, front tooth crowns are more expensive.

Type of crown

Prices

Strenth/durability

Aesthetics

Other commments

Metal

$500 - $1,500

$800 - $2,000

$600 - $1,800

$700 - $2,000

Very long lasting; excellent

If you need more than one, your dentist may offer a slightly lower price per crown. However, the material costs and fitting time per crown stay pretty much fixed regardless of how many you have.

items.title: Why Do You Need A Dental Crown?
items.summary: Why Do You Need A Dental Crown? If you are unhappy with the appearance of your front teeth, such as crooked or broken ones, it is worth speaking to your Auburn dentist about getting a crown. One of five solutions to a chipped tooth is…
items.content_html:
Why Do You Need A Dental Crown?

If you are unhappy with the appearance of your front teeth, such as crooked or broken ones, it is worth speaking to your Auburn dentist about getting a crown. One of five solutions to a chipped tooth is a dental crown. This treatment will undoubtedly give you beautiful smile.

Upon your initial consultation with Dr. Luminita and her team, we will explore what treatments are available to you. Installing a dental crown requires drilling your tooth, so some patients might prefer a more conservative approach at first such as dental bonding (a white filling) or veneers.

This is a great option for your front teeth. They can be durable and last many years if you take care of them. Our team will not place porcelain veneers on one tooth as matching can prove difficult.

Do I Need A Crown?

In addition to offering durable protection, dental crowns are recommended for the treatment of fractured or cracked teeth, as well as to help hold a dental bridge in place. Fixed Dental Crowns can also be used to mask discolored and misshaped teeth.

Are you wondering "do I need crowns?" If you are, here are some of the most common reasons a crown might be needed:

  • Protecting & restoring broken teeth
  • A dental bridge is held in place
  • Recoloring your tooth
  • Covering dental implants
  • Fillings can be restored
  • After root canal treatment, protecting the tooth and root structure
  • Teeth gaps can be closed

items.title: Dental Crown
items.summary: Dental Crown Information about Dental Crowns A dental crown is a useful dental treatment that can extend the life of your natural tooth. It will help strengthen the tooth and also protect it from further damage. Most of the dental crowns that Dr. Tu places…
items.content_html:
Dental Crown

Information about Dental Crowns

A dental crown is a useful dental treatment that can extend the life of your natural tooth. It will help strengthen the tooth and also protect it from further damage. Most of the dental crowns that Dr. Tu places are made of porcelain because they resemble natural teeth and are highly durable. A dental crown is a tooth-shaped "cap" that is cemented to a natural tooth. It will completely encase the tooth down to the gum line. The top reasons Dr. Tu utilizes tooth crowns include:

  • Cosmetic enhancement
  • After a tooth receives a root canal
  • When a tooth is fractured or broken
  • Severe decay
  • When a dental filling is cracked

How Much Does a Dental Crown Cost when you go to an In-Network Dentist vs. Out-OfNetwork Dentist

Cost will also vary depending on whether you go to a in-network vs an out-of-network dentist. Even though in both cases your restoration would be covered at 50%, in the latter case your out-of-pocket would be much higher. This is because dentists in-network are required to follow a fee schedule and have to be contracted with insurance companies.

For example, if you go in-network and the cost of a crown is $1000, your out-of-pocket would be $500. However, if you go to an out-of-network dentist, he or she may charge $1300 for that same procedure, putting your out-of-pocket obligation at $650 ($150 more than in the first case).

However, you should not base your healthcare decisions solely on price. If you like your dentist, has good reviews or comes highly recommended, it might be worth paying for that added peace of mind.

Be aware of instances where larger practices might try to increase their fees by charging extra services that you don't need. For example, billing for gum surgery when it isn't necessary.

Your best bet is to set up an appointment with your preferred dentist first. Have their staff do a complimentary insurance check to see what your dental insurance will cover and what your portion will be.

You can now ask other dentists for information to ensure that your fees are reasonable. Don't base your decision on the price. A friendly staff, the doctor's bedside manner and even the labs and materials he or she uses might be worth the extra financial investment.

Inlays And Onlays

Also known as partial crowns, inlays and onlays are custom-made restorations for patients with worn, damaged teeth. Inlays are used to cover the chewing surfaces between the cusps or sides of the teeth. The entire tooth surface, including its cusps, is covered by onlays.

Both inlays and onlays are made of composite resin or porcelain material. Inlays and onlays are able to blend with your natural smile. Like tooth crowns, inlays and onlays are attached to a prepared tooth. These are made to match the shape of your tooth. For long-lasting restorations, inlays and onlays can be attached to the teeth with resin.

The Best Dentist Crown Material

Each of the materials has its own set of advantages and disadvantages, so the right crown material for you will depend on which teeth are being capped, how you want them to look esthetically, and how long you need them to last.

Ceramic crowns can be made in a laboratory and are built layer by layer using CAD/CAM technology. Ceramic crowns have a translucent look similar to natural teeth, making them popular for front teeth. You can even create them chairside with a new technology that mills crowns in a matter of minutes. They are easy to complete in one visit, and don't require a provisional cap.

Ceramic materials can be weaker than metal, and are more susceptible to cracking or breaking over time. However, if fabricated properly, ceramics should last for at least 15 years. Some ceramic crowns, like Emax caps, are designed differently to be more durable.

Gold dental crowns and those made from other alloy metals tend to be much more durable. Biocompatible means that the crowns can be used with any teeth. Caps are not likely to cause damage or wear. If the patient takes care of it, a gold crown will last for a long time.

Any metal crown has one major drawback: the color. A lot of people don't like a silver or gold-colored crown on their teeth, no matter how it may be hidden at the back.

Others find a crown of gold very appealing. They may even go so far as to have the crown engraved with or studded in gemstones.

Tooth cap prices can vary from one clinic to the other, as with all dental treatments. If you are looking to crown more than one tooth, it is worth shopping around.

There is also more to consider than just the cost of a tooth cap; as discussed above, there are pros and cons to each type of crown. Ask your dentist for information about costs of dental crowns. Also, ask about other options. It is a good idea to inquire about the options available to you from your dentist if you find yourself in similar circumstances.

Full ceramic crowns, on the other hand, are more expensive than full metal ones. Front tooth crowns can be more costly as more time needs to be put into giving them a natural look.

Types of crown

Cost

Strenth/durability

Aesthetics

Metal

May gradually wear away other teeth it bites against

Can gradually wear away other teeth it bites against

If you need more than one, your dentist may offer a slightly lower price per crown. The material cost and time required to fit a crown are the same regardless of the number.

What is a Dental Crown?

With a dental crown (dental cap), you can improve the strength and durability your teeth. Crowns can give your teeth a more natural look. Crowns can be used in many different situations. They can be placed over cracked teeth. A crown is a good option if you need to replace an older filling. If you have severe tooth decay, you can fix it with a crown. We custom-make all crowns. You can choose from a variety of materials. The materials used depend on your specific case. The color of the new teeth will match your existing teeth. This way, you create a uniform appearance.

A dental examination can help us to determine if you need a crown. In our dental office, we examine your gums and teeth. This helps us determine if you're a viable candidate for this procedure.

Blue Island Smiles

Picture this: you visit your dentist for your annual checkup. Your first visit goes well. But, while you are still open-mouthed, the dentist says something to you that causes you to panic.

"Well, it looks like you're going to need a crown."

The most common type of restorative dentistry is crowns. This simple cap can be used to protect or strengthen a tooth or dental bridge, as well as make it look more beautiful. Unfortunately, the procedure of getting a crown can be scary for many patients - but it doesn't have to be!

Knowing what to expect from your dental crown appointment is a great way to make the process less daunting. So today, let's discuss the process of getting a crown.

Receiving A Dental Crown In Detail Dental

Having a dental crown placed will require at least two visits to Detail Dental area dentist office. During the first visit, Dr. Tu will prepare the tooth. He will first administer local anesthetic. Then he will remove all old fillings, debris, and the decayed portion of the tooth. The tooth will need to be shaped so that the crown fits properly. Next, he will take several impressions of your teeth that will be used to fabricate the tooth cap. Finally, Dr. Tu will attach a temporary crown to your tooth. This is necessary in order to preserve the tooth while the permanent crown is made.

It will take around two weeks to receive the permanent dental crown from the dental laboratory. We will then schedule the second appointment to place your cap. First, Dr. Tu will remove the temporary crown and thoroughly clean the tooth. Then the new cap will be cemented onto your tooth for a permanent fit. We will send you home with instructions on how to care for your new tooth crown.

How To Avoid Issues With Your New Dental Crown

Once your new dental crown has been placed, focus on practicing good oral hygiene to avoid developing oral health problems that can lead to issues with your new crown.

Pay attention to the way your crown feels in your mouth. You should make an appointment to see your dentist immediately if you feel any discomfort, pain or sensitivity around the tooth.

To learn more about caring for a new dental crown or to schedule an appointment, we welcome you to contact Dentistry of Detail Dental today.

How is your crown made?

You can make crowns from many different materials. Metal alloys, ceramics, porcelain, porcelain fused to metal or composite resin may be used. The crown material is often tooth-colored to match your natural teeth.

You want your crown to look natural and fit comfortably in your mouth. Your dentist and you will discuss many aspects when deciding on the material for your crown.

  • the tooth's location and function
  • the position of the gum tissue
  • The amount of your tooth visible when you smile
  • the color or shade of the surrounding teeth

You should discuss and consider insurance and costs. You might also want to discuss your individual preferences after you have reviewed these issues with your dentist.

So What Is The Average Cost Of A Tooth Crown?

According to an estimate made by Costhelper , the price range of dental crowns per tooth today can be as follows:

  • Gold crowns are available in a range of prices, from $600-$2,500
  • All-porcelain crowns can range between $800-$3,000
  • Porcelain-fused-to-metal crowns can cost $500-$1,500
  • Zirconia Crowns & E-max Crowns are approximately equal in price to all-porcelain crowns

If you have insurance, about 50% of the crown can be covered. But everything will depend on the type of insurance you have, and your particular case.

If the crown is part of a cosmetic treatment, your insurance plan will most likely not cover the cost of it. But if the treatment is preventative (to cover a root canal or repair a broken tooth) the cost can be covered by your insurance (or at least a percentage of it).

Step-By-Step Process For A Dental Crown

  • To ensure comfort, a local anesthetic will be applied.
  • To ensure comfort, a local anesthetic will be applied.

A local anesthetic is applied to ensure your comfort.

  • By shaping and filling the teeth, the dentist prepares them for crowns.
  • The dentist prepares the tooth for the crown by shaping the outer tooth structure and removing any existing decay or filling material.

By shaping and filling the teeth, the dentist prepares them for crowns.

  • In our office, an intraoral 3D scan of the prepared tooth is captured to send an exact replica to the dental lab. There are no more uncomfortable, gooey impression molds.
  • An intraoral 3D scan is taken of the tooth to capture it in our office. This allows us to create a exact replica for the lab. There are no more uncomfortable, gooey impression molds.

In our office, an intraoral 3D scan of the prepared tooth is captured to send an exact replica to the dental lab. There are no more uncomfortable, gooey impression molds.

  • The temporary crown is a filler that covers the gap and protects your tooth. We then attach it using temporary dental cement.
  • We make a temporary crown that fills in the space and protects the tooth, then affix it to your tooth using temporary dental cement.

We make a temporary crown that fills in the space and protects the tooth, then affix it to your tooth using temporary dental cement.

  • This temporary crown is for you. Specific care instructions will be provided until we see you again.
  • This is your temporary crown. Specific care instructions will be provided until we see you again.

This is your temporary crown. Specific care instructions will be provided until we see you again.

  • We place the final crown on the tooth and confirm the correct fit with a close-up x-ray.
  • We place the final crown on the tooth and confirm the correct fit with a close-up x-ray.

The final crown is placed on the tooth, and we confirm its fit by taking a close-up photo.

  • Any necessary adjustments will be made to the bite until your new crown feels perfectly comfortable.
  • All adjustments to your bite will be made until you feel completely comfortable.

Any necessary adjustments will be made to the bite until your new crown feels perfectly comfortable.

Materials for Dental Crowns

There are various materials that can be used to construct a dental crown, including:

  • Precious metal-bonded porcelain: the most common material used for crowns. The base is made of precious metal for increased strength and porcelain is layered over it for improve aesthetics.
  • Porcelain is less durable than bonded porcelain, but it provides an extremely natural appearance for aesthetic purposes such as to cap front teeth.
  • Ceramic is a flexible metal-free material which can look similar to porcelain.
  • Glass can be used anywhere on the lips for an extremely natural appearance.
  • The gold-alloy is a classic material, which is strong and can be used in many applications. It is also available in silver or golden color.

How do Dental Crowns Work?

  • Ceramic: Often used to restore the front teeth because of their natural color, ceramic crowns are made of a porcelain-based material.
  • Resin: Most often used for a temporary crown, resin is the least-durable option. Resin may have a short lifetime due to its tendency to fracture.
  • Porcelain fused to metal: This is a stronger option than regular porcelain, as it is fused to the metal structure; it is highly durable.
  • Base metal alloys: Very durable crown can be made of non-noble metals that are corrosion-resistant.
  • Gold alloys: Gold bonds strongly to the tooth and is unlikely to fracture; these crowns are made of a mixture of gold, copper, and other metals.

Why Dental Crowns Are Used

There are many uses for dental crowns, including:

  • Protect a weak tooth. Teeth can decay, break, crack, and chip. To keep the tooth together, a cap is placed over it. A protected tooth means a healthier smile!
  • To restore a broken tooth. Caps can also be used to restore a tooth that is severely worn down.
  • Improve your smile. You can instantly improve your smile by covering any discolored or damaged tooth.
  • To provide support for a dental bridge. A dental bridge requires two healthy teeth on either side. If the bride needs further support, a dental crown may be needed.

Looking to improve the appearance or healthiness of your smile? A dental cap could be the right solution for you!

Crown Application Process

In order to get the crown, your dentist will usually need to visit you twice. During the first visit, your dentist will file down your tooth and shape it in preparation for the crown. A temporary crown is fitted to you for the first visit. The permanent crown will then be placed at the second appointment.

When you arrive for your first appointment, your dentist will start by numbing your mouth with some local anesthetic. You'll then be asked to bite onto some carbon paper to see how the crown needs to be placed in order to not interfere with your bite. Then, your dentist will insert a dental dam in your mouth before using a drill to reshape your tooth. This process will cause vibrations, but not pain. The impression of the tooth will then be taken and sent to a laboratory. The temporary crown will be made by your dentist using a special material. This temporary crown can then be worn until the next visit.

You'll need to take a few precautions when wearing a temporary crown:

  • Try the other side.
  • Avoid sweetened foods such as caramel and taffy.
  • Instead of lifting the crown, floss around the tooth and not lift it.

When you return to have the permanent crown attached, your dentist will numb your mouth once again, remove the temporary crown, and then use cement to attach the permanent crown.

A same-day porcelain crown can be made using CAD/CAM technology. This will save you the hassle of having to use temporary crowns. It should only take your dentist about 20 minutes to make the crown.

After your permanent crown has been placed, you will be able to care for it as you would any natural tooth. Brush at least twice a day, and floss daily as recommended by your dentist. Regular checkups with your dentist are recommended so that they can monitor the crown and spot any issues early.

Contact your dentist if you have any symptoms after a crown is placed.

  • Pain when chewing
  • Pain in your jaw or head
  • Crowns with a loose, wiggly feel
  • Jagged or rough spots on the crown

It's normal for the crowned tooth to feel a bit sensitive to heat and cold after treatment. If the sensitivity persists for more than a week, contact your dentist.

The cost of dental crowns varies widely based on the type of crown you choose, the condition of the underlying tooth, and the economy in your local area. A single crown can cost anywhere between $800 and $3,000 The most expensive crowns are metal and PFM, while porcelain crowns that were made with CAD/CAM technology can be ordered the same day.

Remember that your insurance policy should pay for all or part the cost of a crown if it is required to restore your teeth or preserve your oral health. Crowns used for cosmetic reasons are not usually covered by insurance.

You can search the internet for "dentists near me" to schedule an appointment if you need a crown, or if your crown is damaged. The dentist will discuss your needs with you and give an estimate on the cost of a crown. Crowns can be used to restore weak or damaged teeth. Many cosmetic dentist patients have been able to achieve beautiful smiles with crowns.

Do Dental Crowns Require Special Care?

A dental crown is not a guarantee for full protection of your tooth, so you still need to care for it as though it were another tooth. Good oral hygiene means brushing twice daily, flossing once per day and using antibacterial mouthwash to rinse it off.

The Bite Problem

To ensure that a crown fits well and feels comfortable, our dentist takes images and impressions of each patient before fitting it. However, if your crown doesn't seem to fit quite right or feels abrasive when you bite down, then it's important to schedule an exam.

Malocclusions can cause excessive wear to neighboring teeth. Contact us immediately if your crown is not fitting properly. This type of issue can be easily avoided with a good fit, but it can also be resolved if it occurs.

Temporary dental crown care

Temporary crowns are temporary and should be handled with care.

Be gentle, but brush as normal. Instead of pulling the floss upwards, floss should be pulled outwardly. This could cause the crown to become loose.

Advanced Tooth Destruction

Crowns are often needed when a large cavity threatens the ongoing health of a tooth. A badly broken or decayed tooth needs to be strengthened with a crown because this cannot be done with a filling alone.

Crowns will hold the damaged tooth in place and protect it. This prevents the need to extract the tooth.

The Tooth is missing

The space from a missing tooth can be filled with a dental implant topped with an implant crown. The implant fills the space, which properly supports adjacent teeth to prevent them from shifting or wearing unevenly and improves tooth function and appearance. To properly support a dental implant, you must have healthy gums and bones. You will need to address any periodontal problems before you can have a dental implant procedure.

 

The crown and tooth appearances will not last forever. Here's why. The crowning will need to happen several times throughout the rest of the individual's life.

When dental crowns are used to make cosmetic changes, they can be a good choice. If those applications aren't needed, then it's best to at least consider alternative approaches first.

Metal

A variety of metals are used to create dental crowns, including:

  • Nickel-chromium
  • Cobalt-chromium
  • Gold
  • Platinum

Metal can withstand constant biting, chewing, and pressure. Because they resist chipping and breakage, metal crowns can last a long time.

Metal crowns have a major drawback: the color. Metal crowns are best for hidden molars.

Tooth alignment or discoloration

For cosmetic reasons, dental crowns may be applied to one or more of your teeth. They can cover discolored, enlarged, or misaligned teeth. With dental crowns, the appearance of your teeth can be improved for a more confident smile.

Other Indications

Dental abrasion

  • Advanced dental erosion

Advanced dental erosion

  • Bruxism is involuntary, habitual grinding of teeth that occurs during sleep.

Bruxism: involuntary habitual grinding of the teeth, typically during sleep

dental erosion

dental abrasion

Crowns Are Meant To Last

If you take care of your crowns, they can last a lifetime. Some crowns can be more susceptible to breaking or chipping than others, but it is up to you how to care for them.

Taking proper care of your dental crown involves:

  • Visiting your dentist for regular checkups and cleanings
  • Brushing and flossing at least twice a day
  • Hard foods like hard candy and ice should be avoided
  • Sticky foods like caramel and toffee should be avoided.
